description: A brass catcher is a bag that straps onto a firearm and catches empty casings (which are often made of brass), rather than let them drop on the ground.  On a gun range, it's useful because it means less clean-up.  In a post-apocalyptic survival situation, it means retaining material for reloading your own ammunition.  This catcher can be attached to any large firearm.  It's rated for 100 casings of 5.56mm NATO, which only covers about half the bag; this is so that the casings wouldn't fall back into the ejection port and cause a jam.

notes: a review on MidwayUSA says the opening (the window through which spent cases drop into the bag) is about 2.5 × 6 in.
from these dimensions, we can assume the length of the entire catcher is 6 in.
we can also assume that height is 2 × 2.5 in. = 5 in.
width/depth seems to be roughly the height of the opening, so 2.5 in. as well
we add another 0.25 in. to width to account for the hinge and the straps

//material: steel is presumed to be the material for the hinge
//mod_targets: removes pistols from possible targets because
(1) the catcher is just too large for a regular pistol
(2) it would likely prevent a pistol from functioning correctly, given that the slide has to move
(so either the catcher's nylon latch cuts, or the slide is slowed down, thus not ejecting or chambering correctly)

//max_contains_volume: this catcher is rated for 100 .223/5.56mm casings
visually, it seems as though only 45% of the catcher's overall capacity is devoted to the casings
this would prevent new casins from overflowing back towards the bolt, potentially jamming the gun
